et: Middle English {it}mathematicalle{/it}, from Latin {it}mathematicus{/it}, from Greek {it}mathēmatikos{/it}, from {it}mathēmat-, mathēma{/it} learning, mathematics, from {it}manthanein{/it} to learn; probably akin to Goth {it}mundon{/it} to pay attention
shortdef: of, relating to, or according with mathematics

dt: {bc}the act or process of {a_link|inducting} (as into office)
{bc}the formality by which a civilian is {a_link|inducted} into military service
{bc}inference of a generalized conclusion from particular instances {dx}compare {dxt|deduction||2a}{/dx}

{bc}mathematical demonstration of the validity of a law concerning all the positive integers by proving that it holds for the integer 1 and that if it holds for an arbitrarily chosen positive integer {it}k{/it}, it must hold for the integer {it}k{/it} + 1

{bc}the process by which an electrical conductor becomes electrified when near a charged body, by which a magnetizable body becomes magnetized when in a magnetic field or in the magnetic flux set up by a magnetomotive force, or by which an electromotive force is produced in a circuit by varying the magnetic field linked with the circuit
{bc}the inspiration of the fuel-air charge from the carburetor into the combustion chamber of an internal combustion engine
{bc}the process by which the fate of embryonic cells is determined (as by the action of adjacent cells) and morphogenetic differentiation brought about
{bc}the act of bringing forward or adducing something (such as facts or particulars)
{bc}the act of causing or bringing on or about
{bc}a preface, prologue, or introductory scene especially of an early English play

shortdef: the act or process of inducting (as into office)
the formality by which a civilian is inducted into military service
